author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: For Malta’s only athlete at the Games, it was a long road to snowboarding in Beijing.
description: Ten years after asking friends on Facebook to help her learn the halfpipe, Jenise Spiteri is the first snowboarder to ever represent Malta at the Olympics.
content: In January 2012, Jenise Spiteri, then a college student, posted a Facebook status that read, “Wanted: someone to teach me how to ride pipe tomorrow. anyone available??” The post garnered two likes, 10 comments and one share.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Some Masks to Come Off in New York
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is expected to announce plans to drop her mask mandate, following the lead of several other governors.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a turning point in New York’s pandemic response that Gov. Kathy Hochul is expected to announce today. We’ll also look at a former bank in Lower Manhattan that will soon be home to immersive art exhibitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Without a Note of Beethoven, an Orchestra Shines
description: At Carnegie Hall, the Philadelphia Orchestra gave pride of place to a once-forgotten Florence Price symphony, alongside new works and a classic.
content: The vast majority of the music the Philadelphia Orchestra is playing in its eight concerts at Carnegie Hall this season is by Beethoven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China’s Anti-Graft Show Is Educational, With Unintended Lessons
description: A documentary created to celebrate the success of China’s anti-corruption campaign instead has aired the dirty laundry of the Communist Party.
content: One by one, the officials spoke candidly on camera about how they abused their power and accumulated enormous wealth. They looked relaxed, confident and even happy as they described bribes, kickbacks and other perks of corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Mexico City: Wood and Marble Mingle in a Stylish Triplex
description: Investors ‘are selling properties in Mexico City to reinvest in other countries,’ local agents say, boosting inventory and tamping down prices.
content: This four-bedroom penthouse apartment occupies the top three floors of an 11-story building in the affluent Lomas de Chapultepec neighborhood, in Mexico City’s southwestern Miguel Hidalgo borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Long Known for a Blunder, Jacobellis Rewrites Her Story in Gold
description: A snowboard cross icon never let a mistake at the 2006 Olympics define her career. A gold medal now doesn’t change that.
content: Lindsey Jacobellis had the finish line in sight, again. Long the most dominant athlete in the racing sport of snowboard cross, she had been this way many times at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Astead W. Herndon
title: New York is dropping its indoor mask mandate, joining other blue states in easing Covid rules.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul dropped New York’s stringent indoor mask mandate on Wednesday, ending a requirement that businesses ask customers for proof of full vaccination or require mask wearing at all times, and marking a turning point in the state’s coronavirus response, according to three people briefed on her decision.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul dropped New York’s stringent indoor mask mandate on Wednesday, ending a requirement that businesses ask customers for proof of full vaccination or require mask wearing at all times, and marking a turning point in the state’s coronavirus response, according to three people briefed on her decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: ‘Kid Reporter,’ TikTok-Famous Bodega, Intriguing Phone Box
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to meet an 11-year-old reporter, think about what book they would want to write, visit a TikTok-famous bodega, look closely at an intriguing photograph and write a short story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Masked No More?
description: Noses — and maybe smiles — may soon make an appearance in some classrooms, now that several states plan to end mask mandates.
content: Today, we’re covering states relaxing mask mandates in schools and the likely end of President Biden’s plan for free community college. Plus, a podcast recommendation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: This Galápagos Volcano Produced a ‘Mesmerizing’ River of Fire
description: When Wolf Volcano erupted last month in a remote corner of Ecuador, its lava trail extended for miles in an orange line so bright that it was visible from space.
content: The videographer Joshua Vela-Fonseca was staying about 18 miles from a volcano in the Galápagos Islands last month when it started to erupt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Andy Newman
title: Couple Accused of Using Foster Care System for Sex Trafficking Scheme
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan say Kareem and Sharice Mitchell trafficked eight women, including two whom Ms. Mitchell had taken in as foster children.
content: A married couple was charged with sex trafficking young women into a prostitution operation on Wednesday — a scheme that prosecutors said in some cases involved the use of New York’s foster care system to gain access to potential victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Syl Johnson, Soul Singer With a Cult Following, Dies at 85
description: He released dozens of records on an array of labels across five decades, and his work was heavily sampled by rappers. He enjoyed a career revival in his 70s.
content: Syl Johnson, a Chicago soul singer and guitarist who built a cult following for his raw sound on 1960s songs like “Is It Because I’m Black” and, decades later, was heavily sampled by rappers, died on Sunday in Mableton, Ga., at the home of one of his daughters. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Despite a Common Misconception
description: Grant Thackray sets the record straight.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to the constructor Grant Thackray, who is making his 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Thackray’s work is more commonly seen in later-week puzzles, with three tricky Thursdays, three jumbo Sundays and a smattering of themeless puzzles to his name. I always enjoy seeing what established later-week constructors can bring to early-week puzzles like today’s, and I was not disappointed!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Bradley
title: Honey, Used for Centuries to Heal and Hydrate, Is in Demand Once Again
description: A new wave of beauty products, from hair oils to hand creams, are harnessing the benefits of this age-old natural remedy.
content: For all its syrupy sweetness, honey is one of nature’s most hard-working creations; rich with antioxidants, it is both a powerful humectant, meaning it’s able to draw and seal in moisture, and packed with potent antibacterial compounds. Perhaps unsurprisingly, then, it has long been prized for its curative and beautifying properties: It’s listed in recipes for healing ointments that were carved into clay tablets by the ancient Sumerians around 2000 B.C. (and later discovered in what is now Iraq). Cleopatra is said to have bathed regularly in milk infused with the golden liquid. And women in Ming dynasty-era China used it to clear blemishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Reid
title: It’s a Fine Time for Fine China
description: More dining at home has led some people to seek out fancier tableware that makes everyday meals feel far more celebratory.
content: Fine china — the delicate, sometimes fussy tableware long associated with wedding registries and your grandmother’s cabinet — has found a new, more relaxed place at the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage on Wednesday includes men’s free skate and women’s snowboarding halfpipe final.
description: Nathan Chen will compete in figure skating’s free skate in pursuit of an individual gold medal, while Chloe Kim defends her 2018 gold medal in the snowboarding halfpipe.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Wednesday with men’s free skate, women’s snowboarding halfpipe final and curling. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Africa Cup of Nations: Soccer Tournament Offers Joy Amid Coups and Covid’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about some of the highlights from the Africa Cup of Nations this year. Then, they will describe a time of coming together that they had with their own community around sports.
content: Featured Article: “Africa Cup of Nations: Soccer Tournament Offers Joy Amid Coups and Covid” by Ruth Maclean and Brenda Kiven
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How to Make a Wedding Easier on Your Guests
description: With 2.5 million weddings expected to take place in the U.S. this year, mailboxes are filling up with invitations. Here, experts suggest ways couples can take some pressure off guests.
content: Read more about the 2022 wedding boom in our ongoing Year of the Wedding series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: West Ham Fines Kurt Zouma Over Cat Abuse Video
description: Zouma, a defender who also plays for the French national soccer team, lost a sponsorship deal with Adidas on Wednesday after a video circulated online of him kicking his cat.
content: West Ham United, the English soccer club, said it had fined Kurt Zouma, a defender who also plays for France’s international team, “the maximum amount possible” on Wednesday, after video footage circulated online of him kicking and slapping his cat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art Names New Director
description: Christopher Bedford, the leader and sometimes lightning rod at the Baltimore Museum of Art, will fill the position left by Neal Benezra, who resigned a year ago.
content: One year after the resignation of its longtime leader, Neal Benezra, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday announced his successor, Christopher Bedford, the director of the Baltimore Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Stern warnings from Europe to Russia.
content: After two days of diplomacy about the crisis in Ukraine, the leaders of France, Germany and Poland said their overriding goal was the preservation of peace in Europe, but they warned Russia of dire consequences “politically, economically and surely strategically,” according to Olaf Scholz, the German chancellor, if the country launched further incursions into Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: In Ukraine Crisis, Putin Faces a Stark Choice
description: Russia can seize control over Ukraine or keep strong economic ties to Europe. It will be hard to do both.
content: BRUSSELS — As he engages in coercive diplomacy with the West, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faces a stark choice: He can move militarily to control Ukraine or preserve economic links to Europe. But it will be difficult for him to do both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Rivian Loses Its Shine as Investors Fret About Production Delays
description: The electric vehicle maker’s stock surged after a public offering last fall but has since plunged, in part because the company failed to meet its 2021 goals.
content: Rivian, a maker of electric vehicles that aspires to compete with Tesla, completed an initial public offering last year that raised nearly $14 billion. Its shares quickly soared, and the company briefly had a stock market value that was nearly twice that of Ford Motor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: As mask restrictions are set to lift in a handful of states, uncertainty lingers.
description: As the Omicron surge begins to recede in many regions of the country, the governors of a handful of states have announced that they will lift school mask mandates in the coming weeks.
content: As the Omicron surge begins to recede in many regions of the country, the governors of a handful of states have announced that they will lift school mask mandates in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Study Finds Sustained Progress for Female Directors and Filmmakers of Color
description: But women of color are still not getting feature directing jobs in Hollywood, the annual report on top-grossing movies finds.
content: For the first time in a long time, Dr. Stacy L. Smith is feeling optimistic. The director of the University of Southern California’s Annenberg Inclusion Initiative has been studying the gender and race breakdown of Hollywood’s top-grossing directors since 2007, and finally has some good news to report. For the first time since her work began, Smith has seen sustained progress for women and people of color working behind the camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Mesmerized
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Shaun White will have a final shot at gold.
description: He advanced out of Wednesday’s halfpipe qualifier.
content: Shaun White has a habit of stealing the spotlight, thanks to three Olympic gold medals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Fine-Tune and Prune Your Phone’s Contacts List
description: Filling in more of the blanks and dumping duplicates opens up new ways to manage the people in your life.
content: Your phone’s contacts app can be easy to treat as a simple address book. But the default versions usually included in Apple’s iOS 15 and Google’s Android 12 can be much more useful — providing specific ringtones, travel directions, birthday reminders and more — if you take the time to flesh out the entries for your favorite people. Here’s a quick guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Sleep No More’ Awakens After a Long Hibernation
description: The pandemic has reshaped aspects of the show, which reopens Feb. 14, but its once and future influence on the theatrical life of the city remains undeniable.
content: The taxidermy birds have been waiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: Microsoft starts a charm offensive to push through its Activision deal.
description: Regulators are expected to give Microsoft’s proposed acquisition of Activision Blizzard — the largest in Microsoft’s history — a tough review.
content: Microsoft on Wednesday kicked off a charm offensive in Washington to gain government approval for its $70 billion deal to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard, saying it would not give preferential treatment to its own games in its app stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Met Museum to Renovate Its Ancient Near East and Cypriot Galleries
description: Construction for the $40 million project is expected to start next year and finish in 2025.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning a $40 million initiative to renovate its Ancient Near East and Cypriot galleries, museum officials announced on Tuesday. The collection holds some of the institution’s most recognizable ancient works from the Eastern Mediterranean coast extending through Iran, including a pair of towering lamassu sculptures — winged lions with human heads — from the ninth century B.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Ahead of Super Bowl, Rams Try to Enjoy the Comforts of Home
description: The team will use its usual practice facility, team hotel and locker room for Sunday’s game against the Bengals at its home stadium in Inglewood, Calif.
content: When the Rams outside linebacker Von Miller last played in a Super Bowl six years ago, his Broncos team traveled from Denver to California a week before the game was hosted in Santa Clara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed nominees commit to not taking part in finance’s revolving door.
description: Three Federal Reserve picks said that they won’t work in finance for years if they are confirmed to central bank positions.
content: Three of President Biden’s nominees to the Federal Reserve committed to lawmakers that, if confirmed to their posts, they would not work in financial services for four years after leaving the Fed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Censure Vote Has Republicans Battling Themselves Again
description: Punishing Representatives Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger was a blunder, many in the party say.
content: Republicans had Democrats right where they wanted them: on the ropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Tonga extends its lockdown in the capital as coronavirus cases rise.
description: The island nation barely saw the coronavirus in the first two years of the pandemic. But after a volcanic eruption, an outbreak among visiting aid workers has pushed up its caseload.
content: Tonga has extended a lockdown in parts of the country, including the capital, until Feb. 20, amid a growing coronavirus outbreak that started among aid workers helping the Pacific island nation recover from a volcanic eruption and tsunami last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Rick Rojas
title: A Product of Public Universities, Michelle Childs Would Be an Unconventional Court Pick
description: The judge is seen by some as a long shot for the Supreme Court, but supporters say her bipartisan backing and the appeal of her humble ascent should not be overlooked.
content: WASHINGTON — It was just before Christmas, and Jean H. Toal, then the chief justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court, was in a bind. She needed an emergency order drawn up, but the courthouse in Columbia, the state capital, was empty. She was relieved to reach someone who assured her, “Chief, I got it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Ex-Casino Executive Gets 1 Year and 1 Day in Prison in College Admissions Scheme
description: The sentence for Gamal Abdelaziz, 64, of Las Vegas, was the longest yet in the continuing federal prosecution known as Operation Varsity Blues.
content: A former casino executive was sentenced on Wednesday to a year and a day in prison for participating in a conspiracy to secure his daughter’s admission to the University of Southern California as a Division I basketball recruit even though she did not make the varsity team in high school, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: The Rise of the Over-50 Fashion Mentors
description: They’ve already seen the trends, chased the goods and graduated into freedom.
content: Carla Rockmore, a Dallas-based fashion designer, started making videos from her closet in the spring of 2020, just weeks into the pandemic. She had been poised to introduce a jewelry collection — an ornate, Art Deco-ish line produced in India — when everything shut down. People had always told her she should try her hand as a stylist, and she considered herself a natural entertainer, so she decided to try something new. In her first video, the camera is low to the ground, offering a wide view of her spectacular closet, which features two stories, a spiral staircase and a fireplace. Rockmore steps into the frame wearing a sky blue coat and red lipstick, bending down from the waist to address the camera. “So, coronavirus,” she says. “What the [expletive] do we do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Affirmative Action and America’s ‘Cosmetically Diverse’ College Campuses
description: A debate on the racial equity policy that shapes college admissions in this country.
content: The Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases, one involving Harvard and the other the University of North Carolina, that could reshape college admissions. Both schools are being accused of race-based discrimination in their admission practices. In the coming year, the court will examine whether it’s lawful for college admissions offices to consider a student’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: An End to Masks in the U.S.?
description: Scientists agree we need an off-ramp, but when?
content: New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island today became the latest states to announce that they would do away with mask mandates. They join a string of blue-state governors who have abruptly abandoned mask rules, even as the Biden administration remains more cautious about relaxing Covid safety measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Status Anxiety Is Blowing Wind Into Trump’s Sails
description: The adverse economic developments resulting from trade imports that produced a sharp shift to the right are still wreaking political havoc.
content: What is the role of status discontent in the emergence of right-wing populism? If it does play a key role, does it matter more where someone stands at any given moment or whether someone is moving up the ladder or down?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Mitch Smith
title: In states easing mask mandates, the reactions are mixed.
description: In Rhode Island, health authorities agreed that it was time for “a new balance” in dealing with the coronavirus. In Los Angeles, local officials greeted the easing of mask restrictions with promises to resist. Boston’s mayor laid out benchmarks for a controlled shift in restrictions, while the top civic leader in Duluth, Minn., announced a clean break.
content: In Rhode Island, health authorities agreed that it was time for “a new balance” in dealing with the coronavirus. In Los Angeles, local officials greeted the easing of mask restrictions with promises to resist. Boston’s mayor laid out benchmarks for a controlled shift in restrictions, while the top civic leader in Duluth, Minn., announced a clean break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay K. Varma
title: When Do Masks Come Off? The Hard Truth About Lifting Covid Restrictions.
description: Policymakers need to be humble about what we don’t know, especially with Covid-19.
content: Policymakers need to be humble about what we don’t know, especially with Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Mask Mandates Lift
description: States loosened up rules as pandemic fatigue grew.
content: States like New York and Massachusetts were among the most Covid cautious in the country. Now they are moving to lift mask mandates as the Omicron variant loosens its grip on the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: The latest vaccine policy in Los Angeles County is aimed at a defiant sheriff.
description: The move will apply pressure to the sheriff’s department, which has a vaccination rate of 54 percent.
content: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors passed a motion on Tuesday that could lead to the termination of thousands of county employees who have not gotten vaccinated or received a medical or religious exemption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Working Families Party Endorses Jumaane Williams for Governor
description: Mr. Williams, New York City’s left-leaning public advocate, is waging a primary challenge against Gov. Kathy Hochul, a moderate from Buffalo.
content: New York’s left-wing Democrats have cautiously eyed Kathy Hochul for months, watching and waiting to see how the state’s new governor — a moderate from Buffalo — dealt with fraught policy disputes over the economy, housing and the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This Pan Sauce Set My Cooking Free
description: A tangy mix of lime juice, maple syrup and Dijon works well with just about anything.
content: In her sophomore year of college, Melissa d’Arabian studied abroad in France, living with a host couple in a town in the Loire Valley. Madame Gabillet cooked dinner every night, and a frequent dish was seared chicken with pan sauce. “She was not very extroverted,” d’Arabian recalls. “A little bit timid.” But as she watched her host cook with confidence in an everyday kind of way, d’Arabian, now 53 and a cookbook author, began to understand that the chicken was not so much a recipe as it was a strong technique. It was, she surmised, “real French cooking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: As Hochul Lifts Mask Mandate, Focus Shifts to Schools
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is ending the mandate in businesses and workplaces, but leaving the requirement for masks in schools in place, at least for now.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — With coronavirus cases on the decline and mask mandates facing pushback, Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Wednesday that she would eliminate the indoor mask mandate in New York but would leave in place a mask requirement in schools, at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Nathan Chen Is Winning by Not Trying So Hard to Win
description: Chen was fixated on winning an Olympic gold medal in 2018 and was crushed when he didn’t. Learning that there is more to life than skating, he says, has made him a better skater.
content: Follow our live coverage of men’s figure skating at the Beijing Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Hans Neuenfels, Opera Director with a Pointed View, Dies at 80
description: A leading proponent of “director’s theater,” his productions had a provocative stamp that often provoked outrage.
content: Hans Neuenfels, a German director and writer whose provocative, iconoclastic productions made him one of the pioneers of modern operatic stagecraft and the frequent target of audience and critical outrage, died in Berlin on Sunday. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘KIMI’ Review: Sure She’s Paranoid, but Something Really Is Out There
description: Zoë Kravitz stars in the latest from Steven Soderbergh, a story that plays with genre, triggers your anxieties and shreds your nerves.
content: Steven Soderbergh has long been one of cinema’s M.V.P.s, a position that he (happily) shows no signs of relinquishing. Since 2016, after a brief retirement from moviemaking, he has found a new auteurist groove with modest resources, fast shoots, boundless energy and a striking lack of preciosity about the medium. His latest, “KIMI” — his seventh feature in five years — is among his recent best. It’s also only on HBO Max, which is too bad given that Soderbergh makes movies even when he settles for the small screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. to Investigate New Harassment Claims Against Commanders’ Owner
description: After conflicting announcements over who would look into sexual harassment allegations made against Daniel Snyder, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league would oversee the inquiry.
content: After a series of confusing and acrimonious public statements between lawyers representing Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Commanders, and women who have accused him of sexual harassment, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said in his annual news conference on Wednesday that the league would conduct the investigation with an “outside expert.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The Biden administration remains cautious about easing masking and other Covid safety measures.
description: The White House is starting to plan a pandemic exit strategy, but will not move as fast as some governors are on lifting mask mandates and other restrictions.
content: The White House has been meeting with outside health experts to plan a pandemic exit strategy and a transition to a “new normal,” but the behind-the-scenes effort is crashing into a very public reality: A string of blue-state governors have gotten ahead of President Biden by suddenly abandoning their mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: In South Korea and other Asian countries, a surge follows Lunar New Year.
description: A spike in cases across Asia has followed this month’s holiday.
content: SEOUL — South Korea reported 49,567 coronavirus cases on Wednesday, yet another daily record notched within the past week and a jump of nearly 13,000 from the day before. The spike in cases, following the Lunar New Year holiday this month, shows no sign of slowing down as infections from the highly contagious Omicron variant spread rapidly through the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: One of Evolution’s Oddest Creatures Finds a Fossilized Family Member
description: Opabinia, which swam the seas of Earth’s Cambrian era some 500 million years ago, was not just a one hit wonder.
content: Of all the strange creatures unearthed from the Burgess Shale — a cache of remarkable Cambrian fossils deposited in the Canadian Rockies — none has been quite as transfixing as Opabinia. And for good reason — with five compound eyes and a trunk-like nozzle that ended in a claw, Opabinia seems otherworldly, like something imagined in a science fiction novel, rather than a swimmer in Earth’s oceans some 500 millions years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Photographer’s Death Casts Harsh Light on the Cold Streets of Paris
description: René Robert, known for his pictures of flamenco, died of hypothermia after falling on a busy road, seemingly unassisted. The death shocked many, but echoed the indifference homeless people face every day.
content: PARIS — On a cold night last month, René Robert, an 85-year-old Swiss photographer, fell onto the pavement of a busy Parisian street and remained there for hours — seemingly unassisted, apparently ignored by a stream of passers-by. When a medical team eventually arrived, Mr. Robert was found to be unconscious and died later in the hospital of severe hypothermia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Will Smith on ‘King Richard’ and His Secret Career Fear
description: The star of this sports drama isn’t planning any special celebration of his Oscar nomination: “We celebrate by creating the next thing.”
content: Will Smith was just opening his eyes “bright and early” Tuesday in Wyoming, where he was speaking at a business conference, when his phone began buzzing. This year’s Oscar nominations had just been announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ashley Bryan, Who Brought Diversity to Children’s Books, Dies at 98
description: A prolific and eclectic artist, he filled his books with Black characters and injected rhythm into African folk tales.
content: Ashley Bryan, an eclectic artist and children’s book illustrator who brought diversity to an often white-dominated genre by introducing generations of young readers to Black characters and African folk tales, died on Feb. 4 at the home of his niece Vanessa Robinson in Sugar Land, Texas, near Houston. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Weiner
title: Bob Odenkirk’s Long Road to Serious Success
description: He was a comedian’s comedian — until “Better Call Saul” revealed him as a peerless portrayer of broken souls. What will he turn himself into next?
content: When Bob Odenkirk’s agent first called him about playing an oily bus-stop-ad lawyer named Saul Goodman on “Breaking Bad” — at the time a little-watched cable show in production on its second season — Odenkirk hadn’t seen a minute of it, much less heard about it. But he readily accepted the gig.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Does the N.F.L. Have a Race Problem?
description: The N.F.L. has five head coaches of color in the 32-team league. What should be done about the lack of diversity among the N.F.L.’s leadership?
content: Update, Feb. 9: Earlier this week Mike McDaniel, who is biracial, was hired as head coach for the Miami Dolphins, and Lovie Smith, who is Black, was hired as head coach for the Houston Texans, bringing the total number of head coaches of color in the N.F.L. to five. The two articles excerpted below were published before those two recent hires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman and Daniel Victor
title: After another heartbreaking fall, Mikaela Shiffrin searches for answers.
description: Simone Biles tweets in support of the American skier.
content: It was a heartbreaking fall, her second in three days. Mikaela Shiffrin sat on the snow next to the course, her head down in her folded arms as she tried to figure out what had happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Can the Rooney Rule Survive? Should It?
description: Prompted by Brian Flores’s lawsuit and a cycle in which only two nonwhite head coaches were hired, the N.F.L.’s biggest diversity initiative faces new debate over if it can be fixed.
content: In any given year, the hiring of new head coaches in the N.F.L. prompts hope and revival for millions of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: State by state, Germany relaxes its Covid rules, even as cases surge.
description: Though case numbers are at a record level, Germany is recording relatively few Covid deaths and stable hospitalization rates.
content: After months of having to shop online, Germans in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein who are neither vaccinated nor have recovered from Covid-19 regained access to nonessential shops on Wednesday, as a number of German states loosen restrictions even with case numbers rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Has a New Climate Envoy: an American Greenpeace Activist
description: Jennifer Morgan, the American head of Greenpeace, has lived in Germany since 2003 and has applied for German citizenship.
content: BERLIN — Germany on Wednesday announced the appointment of a new international climate envoy — an American, Jennifer Morgan, who is the current executive director of Greenpeace International.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: After retail investors’ rebellion, the S.E.C. wants a stock market makeover.
description: The agency is proposing to cut in half the time required to complete stock trades.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants to shorten the time it takes to complete a stock trade, a change agency officials believe will reduce market risk, according to a proposal announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Behind Wall Street’s Big Paydays
description: Banks worry outsized compensation may not be enough to hold onto top performers.
content: Big banks are responding to the “Great Resignation” by writing big checks. To keep workers from leaving, Wall Street institutions have been raising pay and bonuses for everyone from senior executives to junior bankers. The thing is, it may not be enough, The Times’s Lananh Nguyen reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Inquiry Subpoenas Navarro, Who Worked to Overturn Election
description: Peter Navarro, a White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, has written and spoken about his work on a plan to get Congress to reject the results of the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol issued a subpoena on Wednesday to Peter Navarro, a White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump who was involved in what he called an “operation” to keep Mr. Trump in office after he lost the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Black Joy to Tech Policy
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: BLACK JOY: Stories of Resistance, Resilience, and Restoration, by Tracey Michae’l Lewis-Giggetts, read by the author. (Simon & Schuster Audio.) Expanding on the author’s June 2020 article about the personal and political power of laughing with her daughter, these 36 essays counter the narrative that Black life consists only of struggle and trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Solar Storm Destroys 40 New SpaceX Satellites in Orbit
description: The geomagnetic incident resulted in the Starlink transmitters drifting back into Earth’s atmosphere, where they will burn up, potentially costing the company about $100 million.
content: Over the past three years, SpaceX has deployed thousands of satellites into low-Earth orbit as part of its business to beam high-speed internet service from space. But the company’s latest deployment of 49 new satellites after a Feb. 3 launch did not go as planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Californians Could Sue Gunmakers Under New Bill
description: Lawmakers are also considering a proposal to require parents to tell schools if they have firearms in the home.
content: As with yesterday’s newsletter, today I’ll be walking you through some of the latest legislation that California lawmakers are considering adding to the books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Joseph Goldstein
title: Here’s Where You Still Need to Wear Masks in the New York Region
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have all announced plans to loosen certain restrictions, but all of them continue to require masks in some places.
content: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are among a number of states nationally that are loosening or ending mask mandates as coronavirus cases fall precipitously from their recent peaks. On Wednesday, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced that a statewide mask or proof of vaccination mandate for all indoor public locations would be allowed to expire on Thursday. But it is not time to put away those masks completely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Mark Walker
title: One Menacing Call After Another: Threats Against Lawmakers Surge
description: A review of threats against members of Congress shows how a mainstreaming of violent political speech has prompted a growing number of Americans to target elected officials.
content: WASHINGTON — Early one morning in November 2019, Representative Rodney Davis, Republican of Illinois, received a profanity-laden voice mail message at his office in which the caller identified himself as a trained sharpshooter and said he wanted to blow the congressman’s head off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: This is how huge a halfpipe is.
description: Snowboarders hurtle down a chute as long as the Space Needle is high and swoop up sides the height of a two-story building.
content: As snowboarders turn themselves into human pendulums in the halfpipe event at the Winter Olympics, they will be flying high and long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘It Was a Crusade’: Karen Brooks Hopkins Revisits Her BAM Tenure
description: In a new memoir, the former president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music reflects on some of the organization’s most memorable stagings and artists.
content: “Fund-raising is like a military operation,” Karen Brooks Hopkins writes in her new memoir, “BAM … and Then It Hit Me,” an account of the 36 years she spent at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. “The odds are always against you. It’s going to be 90 percent rejection with many ‘casualties’ along the way, and you must constantly shift your strategy to find new ways forward.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Ryan Cochran-Siegle’s Stunning Success at the Olympics Took a Village
description: The American skier’s ascent to ski racing’s mountaintop and a silver medal in the super-G is a tribute to the strength and influence of his extended skiing family.
content: Seconds after Ryan Cochran-Siegle dashed across the finish line to win an Olympic silver medal for the United States in the men’s super-G on Tuesday, he abruptly stopped next to a television camera. Peering at the lens, Cochran-Siegle, in homage to his home state, said: “What’s up Vermont?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Trude Feldman, White House Reporter Who Got Access, Dies at 97
description: She was known to lob softballs in interviews, but she was tireless in getting face time with officials, including every president from Lyndon Johnson to George W. Bush.
content: Trude Feldman, a second-string member of the White House press corps whose insistent approach to seeking access and softball questions won her exclusive interviews with American presidents and other world leaders, died on Jan. 23 in Washington. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Court Orders Uganda to Pay $325 Million in Reparations to Congo
description: The International Court of Justice awarded the sum over Uganda’s role in conflicts in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
content: THE HAGUE — Judges at the International Court of Justice on Wednesday ruled that Uganda must pay $325 million in reparations to the Democratic Republic of Congo for its role in conflicts in Congo’s resource-rich Ituri province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: U.S. overnight broadcast coverage includes speedskating and luge.
description: The men’s 1,500-meter short track has developed into a rivalry between China and South Korea
content: U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games in the early morning hours on Wednesday. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Discovery’s merger with WarnerMedia clears antitrust scrutiny.
description: In the coming weeks, Discovery will have a shareholder vote, which is widely expected to pass, and will have to begin raising more than $30 billion in debt for the deal.
content: Discovery and AT&T cleared a significant regulatory hurdle on Wednesday that put the two companies on a glide path to close a deal to combine Discovery and WarnerMedia in the next two or three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Jesus Jiménez
title: This Is the Couple Charged With Laundering Billions in Stolen Bitcoin
description: Before being accused in a major cryptocurrency conspiracy, Ilya Lichtenstein and Heather Morgan shared advice, ideas and amateur rap videos online.
content: Before they were charged on Tuesday with conspiring to launder $3.6 billion in Bitcoin stolen from one of the world’s largest virtual currency exchanges, Ilya Lichtenstein and his wife, Heather Morgan, dispensed advice and opinions on the cryptocurrency’s prospects and the importance of safeguarding your stash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: John Rice Irwin, Guardian of Appalachia’s Past, Dies at 91
description: He created the nation’s premier museum of Appalachian history by conserving the log shacks and heirlooms of the mountain folk in his native region.
content: John Rice Irwin, who collected more than a quarter million artifacts of rural life and established the Museum of Appalachia, a sanctuary for the vanishing folk ways of his ancestors, died on Jan. 16 in Clinton, Tenn. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Finns Don’t Wish ‘Finlandization’ on Ukraine (or Anyone)
description: The Cold War term for a kind of stifled sovereignty has gained attention as a possible solution to the standoff with Russia. But the nation it’s named for would rather forget about it.
content: HELSINKI — For decades, Finland survived as an independent and unoccupied democracy in the shadow of the Soviet Union by handing the Kremlin outsized influence over its politics and hewing to a delicate neutrality during the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul says New York State will drop its mask-or-vaccine mandate.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Wednesday that New York State would drop its stringent mask-or-vaccine mandate, which required businesses to demand proof of full vaccination or mask-wearing at all times in indoor public spaces.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Wednesday that New York State would drop its stringent mask-or-vaccine mandate, which required businesses to demand proof of full vaccination or mask-wearing at all times in indoor public spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Boston Fed names Susan M. Collins as its new president.
description: She will replace Eric S. Rosengren, who retired as the Boston Fed’s president last year.
content: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston has selected Susan M. Collins, a University of Michigan economist and administrator, as its new president — making her the first Black woman to lead a regional reserve bank in the Fed system’s 108-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Masks, Trucker Protests, Olympics: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Stock Trading Ban for Lawmakers Gains Momentum on Capitol Hill
description: A bipartisan push is growing to bar members of Congress from trading individual stocks, an effort pushed by vulnerable lawmakers eager to take on perceived corruption in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — An effort to strictly control stock ownership by members of Congress is gathering momentum on Capitol Hill for the first time in a decade, fueled by politically vulnerable lawmakers who recognize the potency of signaling to voters that they will act on the perceived corruption in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Johnson Outlines Plan for Lifting All Virus Restrictions in England
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is fighting to save his job, said the easing of rules would come a month earlier than planned.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain outlined plans on Wednesday to lift remaining coronavirus restrictions within weeks, including the legal requirement for those who test positive to isolate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Neanderthals and Humans Agreed About One Thing: This Cave
description: A new paper suggests Neanderthals and Homo sapiens alternately settled the same shelter more than 50,000 years ago.
content: Tens of thousands of years ago, the hottest real estate in Europe was a rock shelter in southern France. Grotte Mandrin had everything a hominin could want. A rocky overhang that offered shelter from the rain. Sweeping views of a valley and the bison and deer roaming below. A prime location in the Rhône Valley, an important natural corridor linking the Mediterranean Basin with northern lands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Colin Moynihan
title: Sarah Palin starts to testify in her libel trial against The Times.
description: Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, claims The New York Times acted recklessly in publishing an editorial that incorrectly linked her to a mass shooting.
content: Lawyers for The New York Times attempted on Wednesday to establish that members of its staff acted diligently and responsibly after learning that an editorial published in 2017 incorrectly linked a mass shooting in Arizona to the political rhetoric of Sarah Palin, who is suing the news organization for defamation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and George Etheredge
title: The Real Reason America Doesn’t Have Enough Truck Drivers
description: A 1,000-mile journey through the middle of America reveals the fundamental reason for truck driver shortages: It is a job full of stress, physical deprivation and loneliness.
content: A faint winter sun slides toward the frozen scrub as Stephen Graves guides his tractor-trailer across the cracked pavement of a truck stop parking lot in southern Oklahoma. Exhausted from another 400 miles behind the wheel, he needs the restroom. But mostly he needs an answer to the same question that dogs him nearly every day as darkness falls: Where can he park his rig for the night?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bateman
title: Smudgy Eye Makeup Makes a Comeback
description: Grungy black eyeliner from the mid-2000s is back.
content: The look made waves at the Paris haute couture shows when Julia Fox sat, vaping, in the front row at Schiaparelli in an all-leather outfit, golden padlock bag and extreme black cat-eye makeup that covered her entire eyelids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: 11 Cabbage Recipes That Showcase Its Range
description: These recipes make a convincing argument in favor of the criminally underrated vegetable.
content: There’s really nothing humble about a head of cabbage: It can play just about any part, like the Sarah Paulson of the vegetable kingdom. It thrives in every possible environment — cooked hot and fast in a ripping-hot oven, braised low and slow until silky, charred assertively on a grill, massaged with dressing or fermented until funky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What Is Nordic Combined?
description: Athletes compete in cross-country skiing, which requires endurance, and ski jumping, the daredevil event that rewards courage.
content: There are three kinds of skiing events at the Winter Olympics. Alpine skiing consists of the traditional events in which skiers race downhill. Freestyle skiing is the newest discipline, with athletes spinning and flipping in the halfpipe or over moguls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The U.S. States That Are Ending Mask Mandates
description: Several governors have moved to ease mask requirements since Jan. 1. Here’s how policies are changing.
content: Several states are moving to eliminate mask mandates as the number of reported coronavirus cases dips to its lowest level since December, when the highly contagious Omicron variant touched off a wave of cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Exercise May Enhance the Effects of a Covid or Flu Shot
description: A 90-minute walk, jog or bike ride after getting vaccinated may boost your body’s immune response.
content: Taking a long, brisk walk, jog or bike ride after your next Covid or flu vaccine might amplify the benefits of the shot, according to a new study of exercise and immunization. The study, which involved 70 people and about 80 mice, looked at antibody responses after a jab with the influenza vaccine or both rounds of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine. It found that people who exercised for 90 minutes right after their shot subsequently produced more antibodies than people who did not. The extra immune boost, which should help reduce their risk of falling seriously ill from those diseases, did not seem to trigger an increase in side effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Jerome Chazen, Original Partner in Liz Claiborne Empire, Dies at 94
description: One of a core group, he helped the company outfit a generation of working women, marketing its lines to department stores in the shopping-mall era.
content: Jerome Chazen, an original partner in the Liz Claiborne company, which helped reshape how career women dress, died on Sunday at his home in Upper Nyack, N.Y. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: When Did Republicans Turn Into a Bunch of Snowflakes?
description: The Senate’s posturing over qualified nominees has got to stop.
content: “I am an equal opportunity foe of antisemitism.” This was the assurance that Deborah Lipstadt, the renowned Holocaust scholar, offered members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday in her confirmation hearing to become President Biden’s special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism. Whatever your place on the political spectrum, she warned, if you say something that smacks of bigotry, she will call you on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: The Supreme Court Has Crossed the Rubicon
description: The voting rights decision is further evidence of an impatient conservative majority.
content: You know the Rubicon has been crossed when the Supreme Court issues a conservative voting rights order so at odds with settled precedent and without any sense of the moment that Chief Justice John Roberts feels constrained to dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Trahan Martinez and Benjamin Hoffman
title: Trial Begins for Angels Employee Over Role in Tyler Skaggs’s Death
description: Eric Kay is accused of supplying Skaggs with counterfeit drugs that led to the pitcher’s death. Kay’s lawyers say it was Skaggs who was Kay’s drug dealer.
content: FORT WORTH — After months of delays, the trial of Eric Kay opened on Tuesday as federal prosecutors began to make their case that the former communications director of the Los Angeles Angels had supplied drugs to a pitcher, Tyler Skaggs, that led to the player’s death by overdose in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A New Axis
description: China and Russia have formed an “alliance of autocracies.”
content: The last time Xi Jinping left China was more than two years ago, for a diplomatic trip to Myanmar. Days later, he ordered the lockdown of Wuhan, which began China’s aggressive “zero Covid” policy. By staying home, Xi has reduced his chances of contracting the virus and has sent a message that he is playing by at least some of the same pandemic rules as other Chinese citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Barrow Group Announces New $4 Million Performing Arts Center
description: The 35-year-old Off Broadway company and training center will open a new space, which will include a 60-seat theater and five studios, in April.
content: At the outset of the pandemic, prospects looked bleak for the Barrow Group, the 35-year-old Off Broadway theater company known for its actor training programs. It pivoted its existing classes online, and then, in July 2020, vacated the space on West 36th Street that it had leased for 18 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Katie Robertson
title: Entertainment Weekly, InStyle and other magazines owned by Barry Diller’s group will end print editions.
description: Six titles owned by Dotdash Meredith will become digital-only publications as the company tries “embracing the inevitable digital future.”
content: Six magazines operated by the media mogul Barry Diller through his Dotdash Meredith group will immediately stop publishing in print and move online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: See the Halfpipe Snowboarders Take Flight in Beijing
description: Chloe Kim and Shaun White began their quest to defend their gold medals with qualifying rounds in Zhangjiakou, China.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics and women’s snowboarding halfpipe final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: A Design Duo Adding Whimsy to Traditional Woodwork
description: The East London furniture makers Wilkinson & Rivera are giving classic silhouettes a playful twist.
content: The East London-based husband-and-wife woodworkers and furniture designers Teresa Rivera, 29, and Grant Wilkinson, 28, have been inspired by many things, but two above all: the writings of the 20th-century English cabinetmaker Charles H. Hayward and YouTube, where they’ve watched dozens of tutorials by different furniture artisans. “You used to do an apprenticeship with one person for years,” says Rivera, “but now you have access to a limitless amount of masters online.” In the spring of last year, the self-taught duo set up their studio, Wilkinson & Rivera, inside a 20-by-8-foot shipping crate in Walthamstow. Their works combine a respect for traditional forms with a sense of play: The pair’s debut piece is an eccentric and whimsical take on the classic Windsor chair, replacing the 18th-century English seat’s straight-spoked back with undulating pieces of wood that seem to shimmy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Here’s How Each Best-Picture Nominee Could Win an Oscar
description: “Belfast” and “The Power of the Dog” will probably face off for the top prize, but each contender has a path to other statuettes. We explain.
content: For the first time in more than a decade, the Oscars have given us 10 best-picture nominees, and it’s an eclectic bunch that runs the gamut from space operas to psychological westerns. But which films have the inside track to actually take home the gold?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Nino Cerruti Gave Elegance a Good Name
description: The Italian designer is credited with having pioneered Italian ready-to-wear. He was also the most elegant man many people ever met.
content: Elegance, Nino Cerruti once said, got on his nerves. It was the sort of remark you can afford to toss off when you are easily the most elegant man in the room. And Mr. Cerruti, who died last month at age 91, embodied that attribute, a quality seldom encountered yet unmistakable when you are in its presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Where’s Liz Cheney? The Wyoming Republican’s Exile From Wyoming Republicans
description: The congresswoman hasn’t attended Republican Party events in person in her state in years, amid a wave of local conservative hostility. “I’m not going to convince the crazies,” she said.
content: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo. — The women arrived in red formal gowns, the men in suits and tuxedos. They posed in a photo booth with a cardboard cutout of former President Donald J. Trump and bid on auction items including a Glock pistol in a gift basket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert O'Connell
title: In the N.F.L., It’s Fourth-and-It-Doesn’t-Matter
description: This season, N.F.L. teams have opted to attempt a historic number of fourth-down conversions based on data modeling. But that risk-it-all trend may not apply in the Super Bowl.
content: These have been some of the most eventful N.F.L. playoffs ever, stuffed with comebacks, tense quarterback duels and games won on final plays. But from a certain vantage point, the biggest play of the N.F.L. season happened back in September, in the fourth quarter of a game between the Los Angeles Chargers and the Kansas City Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Violence Erupts at Syrian Camp for ISIS Families, Leaving a Child Dead
description: Security forces say they opened fire this week after they were attacked by women and children at Al Hol camp in northeastern Syria, which holds about 60,000 family members of former ISIS fighters.
content: QAMISHLI, Syria — At a detention camp in northeastern Syria where tens of thousands of family members of Islamic State fighters have been held for years, guards opened fire on residents this week after women and children attacked them with rocks and knives, according to a top security commander for the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Hersh
title: Whoopi Goldberg Apologized. Punishing Her Further Is Un-Jewish.
description: The better answer in these situations is obvious, but not easy: education, education, education.
content: When Whoopi Goldberg said on her television program, “The View,” that the Nazi genocide of European Jews was not about race, but was actually about man’s cruelty to man, she showed a flawed understanding of race and of the Holocaust, and offended just about every Jewish organization and Jewish individual I know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Jin Yu Young
title: How the ‘Garlic Girls’ Overcame Abuse to Return to the Olympics
description: The South Korean curling team helped revive a painful discussion about the mistreatment of athletes in their country, leading the way for others to come forward.
content: BEIJING — They were the feel-good story of the Winter Olympics in 2018: young women from a remote farming county who catapulted South Korea to curling glory by winning its first Olympic medal in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The U.S. hasn’t yet won any gold medals in Beijing.
description: This is the third time the Americans have reached the fifth day of a Games without having attained the top honor in any event.
content: As of Tuesday, 31 gold medals had been awarded at the Winter Olympics, with Norway and Sweden picking up four of them to lead the pack. The United States has yet to win any golds, earning one bronze and four silver medals so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Recipe for Instant Olympians: Mix Quickly, Serve Over Ice
description: Many of the men’s hockey players in Beijing expected to watch the Winter Games on TV. Then the N.H.L. decided not to send its players, and the game changed.
content: BEIJING — Early last fall, Hockey Canada’s chief executive, Tom Renney, placed a secret call to a retired scout named Blair MacKasey.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eileen Gu fervor takes over China’s social media.
description: Beijing Olympics achievements by the skier, who was already popular in China, are blowing up the internet.
content: You know Eileen Gu is a hot topic in China when even the transportation ministry joins in the celebration of her gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: What Happens When a Stealth Jet Ends Up on the Ocean Floor?
description: Here’s how the Navy might recover a $94 million F-35 Joint Strike Fighter that crashed in China’s backyard.
content: WASHINGTON — On Jan. 24, one of the U.S. Navy’s most expensive warplanes crashed as it tried to land on an aircraft carrier and sank to the bottom of the South China Sea. The $94 million F-35 Joint Strike Fighter is now the subject of a salvage operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Book Banning Is About the Illusion of Parental Control
description: If students really want to read “Maus,” they’ll find a way.
content: Last week, the book publisher Lisa Lucas started a conversation on Twitter about all of the potentially disturbing, sometimes naughty books that some kids of our vintage used to read without our parents paying the least bit of attention. “Flowers in the Attic,” a creepy, gothic tale of incest and child abuse by V.C. Andrews was a popular one, and I remember it getting passed around one summer at sleep away camp when I was 11. It scared the daylights out of me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Irwin Young, Patron of Independent Filmmakers, Is Dead at 94
description: As the head of a prominent film processing laboratory, he helped directors like Spike Lee, Michael Moore and Frederick Wiseman early in their careers.
content: Irwin Young, who through his Manhattan film processing laboratory gave support to the early careers of directors such as Spike Lee, Frederick Wiseman and Michael Moore, died on Jan. 20 in Manhattan. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Smart, Playful Book About the Underappreciated Index
description: Dennis Duncan’s entertaining and informative “Index, A History of the” moves from the 13th-century origins of the form to the world of digital search engines.
content: Before reading “Index, A History of the,” an appealingly titled new book by Dennis Duncan, I had never thought of the index as much more than a tool — a handy list of subjects and proper names, typically at the end of a nonfiction book, guiding me to the page(s) where I might find the information I seek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal, Rachelle Bonja, Chelsea Daniel, Austin Mitchell, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Movement to Fight Misinformation …With Misinformation
description: A parody conspiracy theory called Birds Aren’t Real has spread widely online, aiming to puncture misinformation using absurdism. Could that work?
content: Birds Aren’t Real, a conspiracy theory with an apparently absurd premise, has become surprisingly popular in the past few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Alberto Rodriguez and Jacob K
title: This Season, Dramatic Duality Reigns
description: Spring’s most eye-catching looks feature contrasting textures — feathers, satin, latex, knits — acidic color and stylized tailoring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Hoffman, Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
title: Life Under the Specter of War: Images From Ukraine
description: With Russian forces menacing from three sides, Ukrainians are stoically keeping to their daily routines, but reminders of the looming threat are getting hard to avoid.
content: The threat is menacing and all around. To the north, south and east, Russian combat battalions, infantry divisions and airborne units continue to mass with a mighty arsenal that includes hundreds of tanks, armor and artillery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: An anti-vaccine convoy forms in France, mimicking Canada’s protesters.
description: Dozens of drivers are heading for the French capital to oppose the government’s vaccine rules, a direct echo of the “Freedom Convoy” protests in Ottawa.
content: Dozens of trucks and vehicles left southern France on Wednesday and headed for Paris as part of a convoy opposing the country’s vaccination pass program, a direct reverberation of the trucker-led protests that have engulfed Canada’s capital for nearly two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Next Vaccine Debate: Immunize Young Children Now, or Wait?
description: It’s not clear whether three doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will adequately protect young children. But the F.D.A. may authorize the first two doses anyway.
content: The Food and Drug Administration’s upcoming review of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for young children is without precedent in recent history.

title: ‘Celebrity Book Club’ Goes Live
description: Steven Phillips-Horst and Lily Marotta, the hosts of a dishy podcast that deconstructs the bizarre genre of memoirs by the rich and famous, branch out with a stage show.
content: Matthew McConaughey loves bumper stickers. So much so, he writes in his 2020 memoir “Greenlights,” “that I’ve stuck bumper to sticker and made them one word, bumpersticker.” Images of these “bumperstickers” — some he’s found, some he’s made — punctuate the book’s text, appearing at odd moments as he narrates his childhood in Texas, his travels in an Airstream caravan, his long-term stay at the Chateau Marmont in West Hollywood (“Back at the Chateau it was always a Saturday”), his romance with Camila Alves, who is now his wife, and fatherhood. As McConaughey, the laconic actor whose credits include “Dallas Buyers Club,” “True Detective” and quirky ads for the Lincoln Motor Company, describes the ride: “my résumé so far on the way to my eulogy.”

content: Good morning. There aren’t many menu descriptions less appetizing than the “blanched lettuce” available at Tim Ho Wan, the Hong Kong dim sum chain that opened its second New York City store in Hell’s Kitchen in 2018. But it’s one of the restaurant’s great options: hot tender-crisp iceberg lettuce doused in soy sauce. I make a no-recipe version at home to go with stir-fries or clay-pot chicken, dressing the cooked iceberg with some oyster sauce that’s cut through with soy sauce and a little sesame oil, along with a whisper of garlic.
